text: [Music]
I think it's very unclear what type of
regulatory reform we're really going to
see over the next 12 months there's a
couple of things that have to
happen that could change the business
materially the first is actually a piece
of legislation that will really prevent
the next Crisis hopefully uh which is
this idea of res solution Authority this
idea that we can actually unwind in an
orderly way an investment Bank an
insurance company like an AIG or or
hedge fund and we've never had that
ability the bankruptcy process doesn't
work very well uh to make that happen
but the larger reforms that have to
happen things like bigger Capital
requirements the idea of having a bigger
safety net a rainy day fund that could
change the business materially because
it would mean that the banks would be uh
safer and less risky there would be less
leverage and therefore debt in the
system and it would actually mean that
the firms themselves would be less
profitable so to the extent there are
profits and they're being given out as
bonuses um those bonuses would come back
inside the firm um and youd put it into
the rainy day fund so all of those
things sound very good the flip side of
all of that is that if you think that
Banks aren't lending today if you tell
them they need to keep more money in the
bank on any given day they would argue
to you that they will be lending even
less tomorrow and what does that mean
for the economy so it's a very
complicated picture and the solutions
while some seem very attractive and it's
very easy to say increase Capital
requirements and long term that's
probably what you need to do given the
economy it's unclear whether you want to
do that
tomorrow well the funny thing about the
gse's now is they're probably not as
well capitalized as you'd want them to
be but it almost doesn't matter because
there is this implicit guarantee that
the government is now it's not even
implicit it's explicit that there's a
guarantee behind them so whether they're
capitalized properly or not is probably
not the issue longer term we're going to
have to deal with that because you would
hope that the government is going to
have to extricate itself from that
relationship and that itself is going to
be a long-term
challenge I imagine over the next 5
years it's going to be very difficult
ult for the government to truly
extricate itself from being in the
business of supporting the mortgage
Market in some way or another the goal
longer term has to be to get out can
that be accomplished in 10 years given
the way the economy is today I don't
know but I would imagine that the fanny
and Freddy's of the world would end up
getting broken up and privatized in some
way or at least that would be the
goal it's it it seems so black and white
and yet it's so complicated
you know I think that some of the
leaders of these
firms had a very bad time hearing bad or
some might have call unattractive
information
and they had people in some cases who
protected them from that
information and when they didn't want to
hear the bad
news they effectively said don't tell me
the bad news
to explain the psychology of why they
did that is a more difficult
question I probably argue to you that
this goes to this whole level of of
hubris and greed at some level but more
about
power
and a sense of entitlement and
a sense
of infallibility really um that once
many of these people got to the
top they they thought they were
King and that in many ways not in many
ways it turned out and is a very
dangerous way to live shareholders
should have been more attentive
throughout this
period but
you know in a bull
market shareholders for the most part go
along for the ride they see the stock
going up and they rarely want to say
anything it's only when it goes down do
they have a
problem and shareholders are sort of
like cats they get hurted around and
they they Follow the Leader with the
exception of a few activist
shareholders there are a very rare
number of of of big important
influential shareholders that like to
step up and say there's a problem here
especially when they're making
money so the good
news is that in the aftermath of the
crisis there has been a deleveraging um
while many of these firms are now taking
on new risk and I think there's lots to
be worried about with that they're doing
it with less leverage so the idea of a
massive crisis on the scale that we just
saw is probably less they're all
instituting all sorts of new risk
policies and hiring all sorts of
compliance people and uh the SEC and the
Federal Reserve are becoming much more
active around these these things having
said that these agencies were around the
hoop the first time and look where that
got
us I think that some firms Morgan
Stanley are good example are taking a
lot less risk um but then on the other
side you look at a Goldman Sach
and it appears that they're taking more
risk so it's it's a complicated
picture unfortunately I think it's very
difficult to separate policy from
politics in a perfect world in some
instances you probably would want to in
other instances you'd probably say that
the political element is important
because it should in a perfect world
match what the stakeholders need or want
or what the public is
after in the case of the
bailouts the politics became difficult
because you'll remember the public
didn't want bailouts and one of the most
remarkable things about this entire
experience when you look at lhan we now
all look at lhan the failure of lhan as
a great
mistake but at the time you can go back
there's an editorial in the New York
Times two days after lean goes back
bankrupt heralding the decision by Hank
pson to let them fail and so it's it's a
very it's very difficult to turn around
and and say should politics and policy
be separate they probably should be in
some in some respects on certain days
and on other days maybe
not well it's it's interesting because
dick F the former CEO of Lan Brothers
has obviously been villainized and has
become sort of the face of the
crisis and what's Difficult about
that and perhaps unfair about that in
some
respects is that most of the other CEOs
who ran Wall Street firms would have
been dick fold had it not been for the
government so you can look at a John
Mack who actually I think did a very
heroic Thing by effectively saving
Morgan
Stanley but it could have turned out a
very very differently five hours later
had Mitsubishi not come to save them or
had the government not made them a bank
holding company the same thing with
Lloyd blank fine the same thing with the
folks at
AIG um the same things at maril Lynch
and
so you know everybody wants a poster
child and it's very easy to wag the
finger at one individual and one face
and that feels the most satisfying but I
imagine in this context it's probably
the most unfair
